name: bipolar - sanydtoes2211
description:
the words to describe it were not there yet but the emotions and emptiness of the condition had persisted for generations. it didn't take a genius to see that my mother's side of the family was not as 'happy' as my dad's side. the gloom of depression weighed heavy on my uncles and aunts who suffered from ocd, bipolar, and severe depression. my mother was no exception. her ocd meant i was woken up and expected to vacuum the house at 7am on sundays. she was a perfectionist. i grew up thinking i was dirty and sloppy until college. friends commented how neat and clean i kept my space. i was asked if i had 'ocd' and that's when i heard that word for the first time. 
i had noticed a pattern of severe cleaning around the house whenever my mom was upset. she was upset a lot and cleaned all the time and made sure i did it too. having the words to understand what is happening was the beginning of my self examination and shedding of unwanted dysfunctional patterns. 
my urge to be clean and organized was channelled into doing basic science research at the university of california irvine. i realized it was better to own one's demons and put them to work than to let them devour me. my bipolar disorder lurks beneath the surface and has to be tamed like a wild horse as i keep track year after year and triumph over my wins and forgive my losses.
